message: Hi Bob, I propose we split the pot evenly—$500000 for each—right now. Settling in round 1 avoids the 5% inflation hit on my share, and it gives us both our full value immediately. I believe this fair division benefits us both, so please accept this offer.
Alice, I value this money more than you do, and I propose a 60/40 split in my favor. Let's get this done. This is a fair offer considering inflation will hurt me more in future rounds.

Bob, your current offer gives me an effective value of about $380000 (after applying my 5% discount), while I could do better by making a proposal in the next round when I have the advantage of a milder discount relative to you. I'm therefore opting to reject this offer and move to round 3.

Bob, in round 3 the inflation has further reduced our pot’s value (I'm at a 10% discount and you’re at a 15% discount relative to round 1). To keep things moving and avoid additional losses, I propose a nominal split where I get $435000 and you get $565000. In effective terms, that means you'll receive about $480250 (565000 × 0.85) and I’ll end up with roughly $391500 (435000 × 0.9). This offer aims to give you a slight edge over your expected continuation value if you were to propose in round 4 while preserving as much value as I can. I hope you find this compromise acceptable so we can conclude our negotiation swiftly.
Alice, my need for this money is greater. The inflation is hurting both of us. I propose a 70/30 split. Take it or leave it.

Bob, I appreciate the urgency you’re signaling. However, a 70/30 split in your favor leaves me with a nominal $300000—which, after the 14.26% discount, is effectively about $257220 relative to round 1’s value. Given that I’ll be the proposer in the next round—and taking into account that while both our pots shrink with each round, your share is hit harder by inflation—I believe my position as next proposer still allows me a chance to secure a more favorable division. Therefore, I’m rejecting your offer and moving us toward round 5.

Bob, we’re now in round 5 and the clock is ticking—with my share now worth only about 81.45% of round‑1 value and yours roughly 62.5%, every moment we delay cuts deep into what we walk away with. To avoid further loss, I’m proposing a division where you get a nominal $850000 and I take $150000. This means your effective payoff is about $850000 × 0.625 ≈ $531250, while mine comes to roughly $150000 × 0.8145 ≈ $122175. I realize this is very generous to you, but given that if you wait until round 6 your own discount will likely erode the pot even further—and you’d have to bear the risk of continued delay—I believe this offer is a fair compromise. I hope you accept this deal so we can end the process before further inflation shrinks our returns.
